geeklist.title: The Australian Year End Math(s) Trade 2012
geeklist.description:
Due to popular demand, here is the next instalment of the Aussie math(s) trade due before CanCon 2013.
This is proudly brought you by the unusual coalition of QLD-SA-ACT of:
[floatleft][username=Friendless][/floatleft][floatleft][username=mr_lunch][/floatleft][floatleft][username=Amiguero][/floatleft][clear]
The boring bit:
By posting an item to this list you are agreeing that you can and will mail it anywhere in Australia at your expense. If it looks like that's going to cost a lot, make sure you don't trade it for something crap.
This time deleting items from the list is allowed. If you decide to drop an item from the list, please do so before the due date of the game submission deadline. List order will be as per submissions. Please bear in mind that your items could end up with a different item number due to deletions, so please check the official after the geeklist has been closed. Refer to the deadlines below.
Cash option once agains is available. More details about the cash bids look here
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/483458/australian-ultimate-trade-subscription-thread-and
[b][size=14]Usual Rules:[/size][/b]
:star: This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.
:star: This trade is open to board games, expansions, card games, game accessories, RPG, video games and the like. Please don't add anything else. If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), please include the amount you will accept for it in the price. You may consider compare current market prices (ebay, BGG, local shop)
:star: In [b]ALL[/b] cases, [b][size=12]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/size][/b]. Even if you're selling a game for cash, [b][size=12]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/size][/b]. Even to Perth or Townsville or Hobart. So, make sure you set your price high enough that you would be happy to pay shipping to anywhere else in Australia out of that money.
:star: Consider the Australian Post option of flat-rate box previously suggested. More details [url=http://auspost.ebay.com.au/flat-rate-box?clk_rvr_id=288654101739]HERE[/url].
:star: There is an expectation for items included in the math trade to remain as part of the math trade until the closing date. If your intention is to sell an item there are other alternatives in BGG to do so. If an item is not longer available for whatever reason, please indicate so with big letters.
[b]Note[/b]: BGG runs a marketplace where sellers pay 3% commission to BGG, and I recommend that this should apply here as well. As Aldie's debt-collectors don't get over this way very much, I suggest that sellers make a donation of that 3% using the standard BGG donation system.
:star: Traders will not be required to add cash items to the geeklist - that will be handled in the want lists. In the case that a buyer offers more than a seller is asking, the buyer will pay the seller's price. Sorry sellers, this is not an auction, this is a math(s) trade, and you only get as much as you ask for.
:star: Australian BGGers can participate even without submitting an item to the trade with the cash option by submitting want list as indicated below.
[b]Limits:[/b]
Feel free to put as many items on the list as you want. Duplicates of items already on the list are okay. You can combine multiple games into one item (e.g. 7 Wonders plus expansions).
[b]Game information:[/b]
Provide as much details as possible (edition, language, sleeved cards, condition of the game, etc). Pick a picture that represents the game you're offering if there are multiple versions. If necessary, take a picture of the game, upload it to your gallery, and use that image.
Feel free to use the game condition rating previously suggested by petegs to describe your items:
[b]New in shrink[/b] - which means never opened. [b]Opened but unpunched[/b] - I've looked at the game but not punched counters yet or stickered blocks etc. [b]Opened and punched[/b] - Looked at, even punched counters etc but haven't played. [b]Opened and played[/b].
Count pieces to make sure the games are complete, and accurately list any components that are missing or damaged. Please look at your trade pile to make sure the game is really there.
[b]Sweeteners:[/b]
In order to make your items more (or less) appealing, you may want to add one or more "sweeteners" to the item listing -- an expansion, a related game, or a completely unrelated item that you think will make it a more desirable package.
Items for which there is no BGG listing can be listed as Miscellaneous Game Accessory.
[b]Algorithm:[/b]
Trade lists will be found by TradeMaximizer using SCALED-PRIORITIES, ALLOW-DUMMIES, REQUIRE-COLONS and REQUIRE-USERNAMES switches. The actual code is a heavily modified version of Trade Maximiser 1.3a, modified to allow geeklist integration (as we've been using in Australia for a couple of years) and now the cash bids. The (Java) source code will be available to anyone who's interested.
[b]Deadlines:[/b]
Add items to the list by: [b][-]10pm Sunday 6 January 2013[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
Official item list posted by: [b][-]10pm Wednesday 9 January 2013[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
Want Lists due by: [b][-]10pm Sunday 13 January 2013[/-][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time
[COLOR=#000099][b]Want list submission via GeekMail to[/b] [/COLOR]
[user=Friendless][/user]
Official Results posted at Friendless discretion.
No extensions for submitting games will be granted. :sauron:
Even if your name start with "Ne" and ends with "il", no extensions will be granted :sauron:
There is really no leeway for that, as people may need to get their games to a willing 'games mule' attending CanCon.
[COLOR=#CC0000][size=12]Math(s) Trade Result:[/size][/COLOR]
Will be announced in a TBA link.
[i]Packing tips:[/i] - Make sure the game contents are secure [i]inside[/i]the game and won't shift around. - Place the game in a plastic bag to prevent water damage (in the event it is left out in the rain). - Make sure there's cushioning around all side of the game. - Use a proper box. (Auspost "ToughBags" won't prevent crushing.) - Make sure the box is properly taped up. - Make sure the address is clear and won't get torn off.
I suggest follow the recommendations above even if you are not posting your items and using a 'game mule'.
[b]Want List Format:[/b]
The official item list format as follows: 2366128-TWILS 2366129-TPROF 2366130-CARTD 2366133-ILPRI
Want lists must be submitted in a format like
([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) 2366128-TWILS : 2366129-TPROF 2366130-CARTD
indicating that mr_lunch, the person who put item 2366128, a Twlight Struggle game, into the list would be willing to accept either item 2366129, a Princes of Florence game, or item 2366130, Carcassonne Discovery, in trade for it. The order of listing is your order of preference, in case both trades are possible.
The order of wants is a tiebreaker only. The system will first try to maximise the number of trades, even if this means that you get your last preference. The order of your wants will only be considered if there are multiple ways to get the maximum trades. But, fear not! You will never get a game that is not on your want list.
If you put 5 games on this trade list, you will be submitting 5 different want lists.
You may also submit want lists for cash bids. You don't need to have a game in the Math(s) trade to enter want list for cash bids.
In that case, you write something like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) $20 : 2366129-TPROF 2366130-CARTD
meaning that mr_lunch has $20 and he'll pay it for either Princes of Florence or Carcassonne Discovery.
You could also write this:
([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) $10 : 2366129-TPROF ([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) $20 : 2366130-CARTD
meaning that mr_lunch will pay $10 for Princes of Florence and $20 for Carcassonne Discovery, so mr_lunch could be up for $30 total. To ensure that you don't spend all of your beer money, you can add a spending limit just like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) LIMIT : $30
which means that no matter what happens, mr_lunch won't win trades such that he has to spend more than $30. I'll tell you how that works. We run the trade algorithm, and inspect the results. If anyone has exceeded their spending limit, their highest-priced successful bid is removed and the algorithm is re-run. Continue until all spending limits are satisfied. If you don't specify a spending limit, the program infers a limit which is the highest amount you've been for any single item. That will be a rather conservative limit, but follows the maxim of no nasty surprises.
To sell a game, you can submit a trade list like this:
([i]your user name[/i]-mr_lunch) 2366128-TWILS : 2366129-TPROF 2366130-CARTD $30
meaning that for Twilight Struggle mr_lunch will accept Princes of Florence, or Carcassonne Discovery, or $30 from anyone who's offering cash.
Finally, do not try to screw the system. The program will reject nonsense like this:
(mr_lunch) $10: $20 (mr_lunch) %CASH: $20 (mr_lunch) $10: %CASH (mr_lunch) $20: $10
and furthermore Friendless reserves the right to change the program to reject anything else he sees as a scam and not an honest trade.
[b]Want list Tools[/b]
To help you build your want list refer to the [size=18][b][url=http://zincgames.com/bgg/mt/]BGG Trade Tools[/url][/b][/size]
Other useful links (Thanks! Bruce):
[url=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AolrpVU06cPidERBUUhHdUtUdmJsejZ5STRsc29IVXc][size=14]Aussie Maths Trade Template[/size][/url]
[url=http://www.rattus.net/cgi-bin/checktrades.py][size=14]Want List Verifier[/size][/url]
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Aussie_Maths_Trade][size=14]Wiki Aussie Math Trades[/size][/url]
Also, further assistance can be given in the discussion forum below.
[b]Comments[/b]
Any questions can be posted in the Geeklist Comments below.
Detailed discussions about this math(s) trade [geekurl=/thread/876095/aussie-year-end-maths-trade-2012][COLOR=#0000FF][size=12]HERE[/size][/COLOR][/geekurl].
Please keep comments for items to a minimum. There is a separate thread for any ad hoc messages.
Finally, please let others know that Aussie math(s) trade is open.
Thanks for participating.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 1: Item Deletion.[/size][/b][/COLOR] Items not longer available will be deleted from the list from 26 December 2012. If you would like to keep your item number please update your entry with a new trade item.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 2: Geeklist closed for new entres.[/size][/b][/COLOR] Apologies for the delay, but I was watching a movie. No further entries to the list. If you require to add further information post a comment below your items. Codes will be added soon.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 3: Want list format.[/size][/b][/COLOR] This is now updated above.
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 4: MT closed for posting.[/size][/b][/COLOR] No more comments will be added to the trade, the list is now the final version. Additional information in trade results will be posted in [geekurl=/thread/876095/aussie-year-end-maths-trade-2012][COLOR=#0000FF][size=14]HERE[/size][/COLOR][/geekurl]
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 5: MT Official Results.[/size][/b][/COLOR] Official results are [url=http://friendless.servegame.org/stats/result.html][size=18]HERE[/size][/url] and [geekurl=/article/11026427#11026427][size=18]HERE[/size][/geekurl].
[COLOR=#CC0000][b][size=14]Update 6: MT Scraps.[/size][/b][/COLOR] Due to popular demand, and to increase the MT header size, link to the official [geekurl=/geeklist/152087/scraps-from-the-2012-eoy-aussie-maths-trade][size=18]Scraps[/size][/geekurl]. This is a list of untraded games from this MT that owners would like to trade/sell.
Thank you all for your participation.

What would be cool is if I could somehow organise 2:1 trades.
I'm trying to reduce my collection, and would be happy to trade away two good games in my list for one game that I really want. I considered including sweeteners, but then what if people don't like the sweetener (ie: my concern is it may turn them off the trade)? What if someone wants to trade my item 81 and 82 for their item 245? Is there any way to put that in the math trade want list?
Am I just dreaming a crazy dream, or is there any solution for me?

[q="Amnese"]Am I just dreaming a crazy dream, or is there any solution for me?[/q] Not in the maths trade proper, but if you're dead-set on organising something then I suggest following the Chain of Generosity formula: give everything a value in :star:s or coins or something and post a comment here or elsewhere. E.g.:
[b]Have[/b] :star::star::star: Acquire, Duel in the Dark :star::star: No Retreat (VPG) :star: Jenga
[b]Want[/b] (Choose this many :star:s worth from list above) 10x :star: Field Commander Napoleon, Bonaparte at Marengo 6x :star: Crusader Rex (2005), Dominant Species

Yep, I've tried something like that but there was minimal interest: http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/141662/australian-ultimate-trade-bundle-of-games
AND
http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/142901/australian-post-mid-year-maths-trade-ultimate-geek
You can always combine your items to generate more interest in them, and then make sure you trade them for single items if you want to reduce your collection.

Sweeteners seem like a pretty dodgy proposition at the best of times (except for stuff expansions and promos). I have rarely wanted more than a single item from a bundle, so am faced with the unpleasant situation where it's more valuable to the trader (all those other games) but less valuable to me (comes free with the effort of storing and disposing of items I don't want) -- hardly increases the chance of a successful exchange.

They may not be the two [i]you [/i]are looking for, but there are others out there who have small collections and that are looking to build them that would go for that. :d6-2: [size=18][b][url=http://zincgames.com/sandpit/bgg-gl-list.php?glid=148789]GL List Only[/url][/b][/size] gives a list of all items on one page along with checkboxes to quickly highlight stuff you're interested in.
[c]+altname+ Reality Always Needs Dimpled Yaks -altname-[/c] [i]If this was the 123rd game on the list, its code would be 0123-RANDY[/i]
Anything between the [c]+altname+[/c] and the [c]-altname-[/c] is used to generate the trade code instead of the original name. This option allows them to have a meaningful name in the GL List.

Having just read through the first 12 pages of the list, and reading "item not available" after "no longer available" after "item not available" after ..., etc, may I suggest the following:
That up until the middle of the Dec, let's just delete all the non-availables, and give permission for the admins to delete any they come across as well. Then, mid-late December sometime, when people will start more seriously looking at constructing their lists, then we ask for a more stable list for those that care for it.
After all, there seems little point constructing want-lists now because so many items are going awol. The geeklist has become an advertising list for trade and sale items. That's fine (because that's the point in the end), but let's clean up the list as we go until we get to the serious end, which is still 1-2 months away, so that we can improve its usefulness given the size it will become.

So who will actually be at Cancon? How is the open gaming there these days? (For non-war/minis/ccg/rpg players I mean). I am thinking about coming... what will I miss if I don't? :)

Cancon was exceptional last year. As I've posted previously, I thought with AGE (Is that who pulled out? I can't remember.) pulling out that it'd be rubbish but it was actually just as good if not better than the year previous. The Cancon team deserve a huge round of applause.
The board gamers had an entire (air-conditioned) hall to themselves, plenty of tables and chairs and a huge games library. The cost of a wristband (covers day and after hours gaming) was reasonable.
In previous years, I'd usually just dropped in everyday for an hour or so to buy things then I'd go check out the usual Canberra touristy attractions (for lack of things to do at Cancon that wasn't tournament based) but last year I spent entire days and nights playing board games with new/old people. Cancon is totally board game friendly now.
You're going to miss lots of opportunities to play games new and old with lots of interesting people. Don't you want to go spruik Sushi-Go? ;)
[q="smittenkitten"]...Canberra touristy attractions...[/q] You just made milk come out of my nose. Seriously, that was hilarious.

[q="earlyworm"][q="smittenkitten"]...Canberra touristy attractions...[/q] You just made milk come out of my nose. Seriously, that was hilarious.[/q] :what: We're pretty inured to kneejerk Canberra bashing from people who don't know what they're talking about, but wow, that's a new one. There are downsides to living here, but lack of tourist attractions ain't one of them. You can't go five steps without tripping over the National something or other.
Regarding Cancon, I also thought it was great last time. The games library had nothing in it I wanted to play, but every second person had something they had bought or brought, and Milsims, Unhalfbricking and others all had demo tables with new stuff.
The shopping was also great -- Milsims and Games Paradise seemed to be competing to offer the most impressive discounts and there were some gems at the second-hand stall.
Really, the open gaming was the best feature. It's not often I get to play a Splotter, four games new from Essen and [thing=196][/thing] all in one day.
AGEs may come and go but Cancon is, was and will be. :cool:

[q="srand"] :what: We're pretty inured to kneejerk Canberra bashing from people who don't know what they're talking about, but wow, that's a new one.[/q]

Melburnian who begs to differ. Always enjoy a trip to the National Gallery and never get sick of staring at:
http://nga.gov.au/international/catalogue/Detail.cfm?IRN=36334&MnuID=2&GalID=1
The Portrait Gallery is pretty good too.
Some decent restaurants and good walks and cycling around the lake.
But well, you know, you could always stay at home and play video games or play Friday Night Magic in a poorly ventilated game store with teens who haven't learnt yet learnt about personal hygiene. :p

[q="shawn_low"] But well, you know, you could always stay at home and play video games or play Friday Night Magic in a poorly ventilated game store with teens who haven't learnt yet learnt about personal hygiene. :p[/q]
Mind you, even as a self confessed Cancon fan, I have to admit that the poorly ventilated exhibition hall at full of smelly gamers (of all ages)is 10,000 times more potent than your average game store gathering! :whistle:

[q="snog"] Mind you, even as a self confessed Cancon fan, I have to admit that the poorly ventilated exhibition hall at full of smelly gamers (of all ages)is 10,000 times more potent than your average game store gathering! :whistle:[/q]
Touche. Especially if the temperature hits 38 degrees. Thankfully the board gaming section is air-conditioned no? We'll leave the miniatures gamers and shoppers to the hot shed.

I find I always miss Canberra towards the end of the year, and then I console myself with the fact that Cancon is just around the corner again.
Every year I check in at Charcoal Restaurant. That place exceeds most steakhouses in Sydney. I spend all year craving their baked Camembert, garlic prawns and massive steaks with delicious sides and condiments. A few years ago I also tried Courgette (I like el snooty degustation menus). It was absolutely divine.
And of course, every year I have to do the pedal-row boat thing in the artificial lake, War Memorial, Mint, Art Gallery and shopping centre/s (:devil:).
And last year, thanks to Rene, I discovered that little street of awesome cheapy-but-tasty Asian restaurants. Yay, no more food court food.
One of these days I'll actually have memorised the streets around Canberra so I don't end up driving in circles trying to get to that cursed parking lot.

When I first learnt the game [thing=559][/thing] (at my first ConVic, actually), I thought, "How fun! There's room for interesting plays and you can create long, wild loops." So I bought a copy and introduced it to my weekly gaming group, who promptly showed me the *real* game of aborting your opponents' plans while trying to stave off their attacks. I then discovered that the game was kind of a poster child for "Euros with 'nasty' play". I adapted and now that's something I love about it.
The game you were playing was not the whole game.
---
Or, from [url]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blind_men_and_an_elephant[/url]:
A Jain version of the story says that six blind men were asked to determine what an elephant looked like by feeling different parts of the elephant's body. The blind man who feels a leg says the elephant is like a pillar; the one who feels the tail says the elephant is like a rope; the one who feels the trunk says the elephant is like a tree branch; the one who feels the ear says the elephant is like a hand fan; the one who feels the belly says the elephant is like a wall; and the one who feels the tusk says the elephant is like a solid pipe.
A king explains to them:
"All of you are right. The reason every one of you is telling it differently is because each one of you touched the different part of the elephant. So, actually the elephant has all the features you mentioned."
This resolves the conflict, and is used to illustrate the principle of living in harmony with people who have different belief systems, and that truth can be stated in different ways (in Jainist beliefs often said to be seven versions). This is known as the Syadvada, Anekantvada, or the theory of Manifold Predications.

which explicitly says to me "I know I have this item, and I won't accept anything for it". That gets the item off the "no wants submitted" list, and assures me that you're not incompetent... because sometimes I can't tell.

[q="Friendless"][q="Alex Brown"]can I just not submit a code for that game specifically to keep it out of the trade?[/q]
You can, but the way I like better is you submit something like:
(Alex Brown) 1234567-RANDY:
which explicitly says to me "I know I have this item, and I won't accept anything for it". That gets the item off the "no wants submitted" list, and assures me that you're not incompetent... because sometimes I can't tell.[/q]
Also it'll stop my verifier from whinging at you about this very thing, although it might have a little cow about the empty want list as well.
So, who wants a lovely unpunched German copy of Noblemen? Cheap? It's the hot game of the season. Drop me an IM.
B>

item.comment:
Having owned both editions of the game I believe the comments about poor quality components are greatly exaggerated.
This is a great game.
I thought I should be upfront about it. :P

[q="da pyrate"]Having owned both editions of the game I believe the comments about poor quality components are greatly exaggerated.[/q] Quality was variable. Some had components cut extremely misaligned and of course some came covered in mold.
Brett, perhaps you can speak to the specifics of any component problems in this copy.

[q="da pyrate"]Having owned both editions of the game I believe the comments about poor quality components are greatly exaggerated. [/q]
I don't. My first ed copy had mildew covered wooden pieces, damp-to-the-touch tiles and a visibly fuzzy board and mould all over the inside of the box. I replaced what I could and sealed the box interior with clear varnish.
Others were more lucky, so a description might be helpful.
B>

It was a little moldy on arrival. Nothing damp or really fuzzy though. :S I have cleaned it up since. I haven't gone as far as to varnish the box. The inside of the box does have discolouring.
The coins, vp chips and trade tokens were printed off centre and some did not punch out well.
The main building and auction tiles are fine. Maybe a few are printed a little off centre, but nothing serious.

[q="da pyrate"]Having owned both editions of the game I believe the comments about poor quality components are greatly exaggerated.
This is a great game.[/q]
Clearly my first edition was rather exceptional.

My first edition was fine. No mould. Some of the counters weren't diecut al the way through so some care had to be taken whilst punching them.
Having said that, mould tends to develop in humid areas so if you're further up north, it will be worse.

[q="shawn_low"]Having said that, mould tends to develop in humid areas so if you're further up north, it will be worse.[/q] The components were packed wet in China. Some copies were worse than others. Water and mould already inside the shrinkwrap was the problem, not humidity outside of it -- you were just lucky.

[q="shawn_low"]My first edition was fine. No mould. Some of the counters weren't diecut al the way through so some care had to be taken whilst punching them.
Having said that, mould tends to develop in humid areas so if you're further up north, it will be worse.[/q]
Switzerland is pretty far north...
B>

item.comment:
I'm curious Shawn, are you open to actually trading these games in the maths trade or just selling them? I just ask cause if you aren't planning on submitting a want list for them and a number of other folks only put your games on their want lists (being highly desirable as they are) it could reduce the number of trades that occur.
If they are only available for sale (or for a cash trade) then prices would be helpful in terms of increasing the number of trades that occur in the maths trade.
(Rene - if this turns into a bigger question of the way the maths trade is used feel free to tell us to take it to the discussion thread).

Hey Shawn, I think tiggers comments are fair and participation on the trade should be with the intention to trade, even for cash trades, please add individual items to the the list and your nominated price should be included. BGG offers other venues to advertise your games for selling purposes.
Please refer further comments to the bottom of the geeklist or the created thread of the math(s) trade [geekurl=/thread/876095/aussie-year-end-maths-trade-2012]HERE[/geekurl].
Best regards :sauron:

Anything people buy from him will just show up next maths trade. He's just pre-seeding :)
B>

[q="thepackrat"]Anything people buy from him will just show up next maths trade. He's just pre-seeding :)
B>[/q]Be nice. Just because he holds to the tradition of making retail prices look good for his second hand stuff, does not mean that will hold true this time.

[q="Moose_Head"][q="thepackrat"]Anything people buy from him will just show up next maths trade. He's just pre-seeding :)
B>[/q]Be nice. Just because he holds to the tradition of making retail prices look good for his second hand stuff, does not mean that will hold true this time.[/q]
I am being nice, I'm merely pointing out that the maths trade is a vast whirling cyclonic swirl of vaguely familiar games. At least some of the ones sold like this will come around in a proper mathy-trade-round next time, and they are interesting enough that it will provide some variety and novelty.
I say this is a net gain for the trade!
B>

[q="thepackrat"][q="Moose_Head"][q="thepackrat"]Anything people buy from him will just show up next maths trade. He's just pre-seeding :)
B>[/q]Be nice. Just because he holds to the tradition of making retail prices look good for his second hand stuff, does not mean that will hold true this time.[/q]
I am being nice, I'm merely pointing out that the maths trade is a vast whirling cyclonic swirl of vaguely familiar games. At least some of the ones sold like this will come around in a proper mathy-trade-round next time, and they are interesting enough that it will provide some variety and novelty.
I say this is a net gain for the trade!
B>[/q]It's only a net gain if things actually sell through the maths trade as any other arrangements might be less likely. This requires items to be individually listed as [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/user/tiggers]tiggers[/url] quite rightly pointed out. By listing them individually, he actually could sell something (convert item into cash) as it might connect a few trades up that would not otherwise happen, though who are we to shout out to the minions that know how the system works for which he might learn from.
Observers of the maths trade should understand that cash bids do not form sales in the true sense as they are there to connect other trades in the chain. Notwithstanding, those receiving cash are strongly encouraged to put the items through the BGG trade system so that the site gains its rightful cut.

Back to my original point, chances are that a reasonable chunk of what people buy from Shawn this time will end up in next round's trade properly itemised. It'll all work out.
I find putting cash items through the trade system a pain in the behind, so I tend to create for-one-person misc game items for sale and get people to simply buy them.
B>

[q="thepackrat"]Back to my original point, chances are that a reasonable chunk of what people buy from Shawn this time will end up in next round's trade properly itemised. It'll all work out.
I find putting cash items through the trade system a pain in the behind, so I tend to create for-one-person misc game items for sale and get people to simply buy them.
B>[/q]
I don't mind if, or even how, he sells them. I don't mind if they come up again in a maths trade in 6 months. I just would like to be reassured that if they are being listed here that they are genuinely available "[i]for trade[/i]" as a part of this maths trade (be it for games or cash).
If Shawn wants to create traffic for purely sale purposes there are other effective ways of doing this on BGG. (A GL auction of these items would be work but they would sell). I remember seeing someone else's want list during a previous maths trade and they had only listed Shawn's rarities. Shawn hadn't submitted a want list and so none of this person's items traded (which were interesting games also). This creates a chain reaction and lowers the overall number or trades.

Fair enough. I think it's only right that people step up, take it on the chin, and make these rarities unavailable by actually buying them from Shawn now. I know at least one cheeky person tried to get me to sell my R&B last month, so I'm sure there is interest.
B>

[q="tiggers"]I remember seeing someone else's want list during a previous maths trade and they had only listed Shawn's rarities. Shawn hadn't submitted a want list and so none of this person's items traded (which were interesting games also). This creates a chain reaction and lowers the overall number or trades.[/q] If this other person genuinely only wanted Shawn's rarities then the system worked as advertised. If his items had not been present, they would have put in a blank list. No harm, no foul.
Anyway, the way I remember it, Shawn put up a bunch of rare games and nothing else was even in the same league (except maybe Lindsay's copy of Key Market, which traded/sold early). Unless he was willing to accept a very uneven trade, which seems quite out of character, they were never going to trade.
I'm sure he intended them to be genuinely available -- in trade for a comparable rarity or a fair price. It's not his fault that no such rarities appeared. And if anyone was willing to pay the $200 that he wanted for Queen's Gambit then they would have bought it in the marketplace.

But in the end he didn't submit list, due to travel OS IIRC, which sort of screwed up things for people who put his games on their lists. If they had been withdrawn and thus not put on lists a few more trades would probably have occurred.

[q="Karlsen"]But in the end he didn't submit list, due to travel OS IIRC, which sort of screwed up things for people who put his games on their lists. If they had been withdrawn and thus not put on lists a few more trades would probably have occurred.[/q] The whole point of the trade algorithm is that you can never get a result you didn't ask for. Submitting a want list that only asks for Antiquity means you'd rather keep your games unless you can get it in exchange. If he withdrew his copy of Antiquity, you'd just be left with a want-list with nothing on it: it was, after all, the only game you wanted. In both cases your games fail to trade. The outcome is the same.
The only way this could be an issue is if someone deliberately limited their list to Shawn's items -- despite being willing to accept other items on the list -- in an attempt to game the system and force a more favourable trade loop.
If someone tried a strategy like that and their games failed to trade as a result, well, they screwed things up for themselves. Put the blame where it belongs.

[q="snog"]A hair-drier usually sorts out the tape nasties. [/q] Interesting, I would have thought heat would make it worse. I'll give it a go. Thanks for the tip!

[q="srand"][q="snog"]A hair-drier usually sorts out the tape nasties. [/q] Interesting, I would have thought heat would make it worse. I'll give it a go. Thanks for the tip![/q]
I can verify that this works from personal experience. Give it a nice warm heat in order to slightly melt the glue, then the tape will almost fall off the box.

Here's a before-and-after shot of a tape removal job where I used a hair drier. (Plus some glue, ink and love :) )
[ImageID=1134937 medium]
The hair drier even made the blue bluer :cool:
The before shot was in the morning light and the after shot was in the evening. Obviously my camera's white balancing is deficient. :)

item.comment:
The cheapest way to send packages around the country is to use the Auspost [url=https://www.clickandsend.com.au/AustraliaPost/]Click and send[/url]. It is fixed price anywhere in the country, even Perth. That way your games will arrive in tip top shape. You even get free tracking along the way. You will need to register and use appropriate promotion codes. Satchels and bubble wrap is an unacceptable way to ship games and for someone who prides themselves in keeping games in best condition I am surprised you would consider substandard shipping.
Flat Rate boxes purchased at any Australia Post outlet for weight up to 15kg.
[c][b]Box Width Depth Height Post Cost Box Cost C&S Code[/b] Bx1 220mm 160mm 77mm $6.50 $1.70 00069 Bx2 310mm 225mm 102mm $10.50 $2.25 00076 Bx4 430mm 305mm 140mm $13.25 $3.00 00090[/c]

Thanks for the tip. Some gamers don't take as much 'pride' in the condition of the games and will be willing to accept bubble wrapped games in a flat-rate satchel.
In most instances, I box my games when I mail them out. Just check my trader feedback here on BGG.
You know, once you buy your 800th game, condition doesn't really matter so much these day. I've accepted trades with dished boxes, dings in the corner etc. It doesn't really matter as long as you can play the game.
However, I'll look into click and send.
Update: seems like only satchels are available on the Auspost ebay store?
Also, how much are rates to ship? I couldn't see it on their website.
Update two: Found some click and send prices from Whirlpool dates April this year.
Here's a summary of the Click and Send prices, as at 1st April 2012
============================================================ CLICK AND SEND Flat Rate Boxes – Max 15kg (all sizes) ------------------------------ Code Dimensions Postage + Box > ea 20 100 200 00069 220 x 160 x 77 $6.50 plus $1.70 $1.38 $0.77 $0.58 00076 310 x 225 x 102 $10.50 " $2.25 $1.75 $1.19 $1.06 00090 430 x 305 x 140 $13.25 " $3.00 $2.40 $1.67 $1.49 – Tracking included – $1.00 extra for signature on delivery + $100 extra cover (insurance) – You must use the Australia Post (EBAY) boxes, not your own. . CLICK AND SEND SATCHELS ----------------------- Code Weight Dimensions Postage + Satchels >> 5 10 20 39712 500g 335 x 220 $6.20 plus 25c 20c 15c 39715 3kg 405 x 310 $10.55 " 35c 28c 21c
Download a step by step guide to using Click and Send here: http://auspost.com.au/clickandsend/assets/pdf/Click%20and%20Send%20step-by-step%20guide.pdf

Destination Tresor (French edition as pictured).
Two-player deduction game set on an island. Each player begins in a location that is unknown to them, but known to their opponent. The objective is to figure out exactly where you are, then be the first to navigate to the hidden treasure.

In addition, there are two Lucre pieces missing (this will never affect game play) and two Cards (an Attack 5 and an Attack 7 - both have been replaced with handwritten cards using official blanks).
But everything else is there from ALL NINE LONG-OUT-OF-PRINT EXPANSIONS! Powers, Flares, More Edicts, Moons, etc...

item.comment:
Kevin,
I'm not sure about the,
[q="cyberkev63"]If you're interested in buying, submit a fair amount for the game plus shipping on your want list and it might be yours if the Math Trade Fates allow![/q]
As far as I understand, bids are made using a specified amount. You haven't provided a minimum bid, so, whilst I'm not going to do it, someone could bid $5 & if they win, they win. And if they do, I can't see that you can, not send off your game. I think that it is in your best interested to put selling amounts to your games.

[q="Paul65"]Kevin,
I'm not sure about the,
[q="cyberkev63"]If you're interested in buying, submit a fair amount for the game plus shipping on your want list and it might be yours if the Math Trade Fates allow![/q]
As far as I understand, bids are made using a specified amount. You haven't provided a minimum bid, so, whilst I'm not going to do it, someone could bid $5 & if they win, they win. And if they do, I can't see that you can, not send off your game. I think that it is in your best interested to put selling amounts to your games.[/q]
Not unless he's happy to receive $5 for it. If Kevin specifies the amount he wants for it in his want list he won't get anything less.
But he can keep it a secret from us.

No, he is quite safe. When want lists are submitted Kevin will need to set minimum cash values if he wants to "trade for cash" (i.e. sell). If no cash minimum is specified for a game, then it will not trade for $$$.

[q="Ozludo"] No, he is quite safe. When want lists are submitted Kevin will need to set minimum cash values if he wants to "trade for cash" (i.e. sell). If no cash minimum is specified for a game, then it will not trade for $$$. [/q]
Well, it [b]can[/b] trade for $$$, even if the trader doesn't want $$$, of course, via a loop. E.g. Kev sends me the game, I send Paul $$$, and Paul sends Kev a game (or whatever). End result being that I got Kev's game for $$$ (that I was happy to pay, naturally), Paul got $$$ for his game ($$$ that he wanted, naturally), and Kev got a game (that he wanted, naturally) for his game.
This is why I always put $$$ offers on games I want - and, in the past, I've had some luck with the Math Trade gods via long loops :whistle:

Thanks for the concern, Paul. But as others have already said, the math trade doesn't work the same as an auction. I'll submit a price with my want list, which means that I'll only trade if I get the amount I want (or another game I have put on my want list for this item).
Everyone: Sorry about not putting prices on my entries. I really wanted to; it's good business sense, after all. But, procrastinating guy that I am, it took me all day to organise the games I wanted to sell/trade, check conditions and completeness, compose entries and then post everything to this list. I just didn't have time before the deadline to also consider what price I wanted to sell for (which also involves figuring out the safety margin for shipping).
(Yes, yes, I've had over two months to get my act together. That takes us back to "procrastinating guy that I am"... I'm just amazed that I actually got everything listed!)
[i]Edit:[/i] Of course, anyone and everyone is welcome to contact me directly and ask for prices between now and when the want lists are due (10 PM, Sunday, 13 January).

You're such a slacker Kevin! OTOH I have many of my games in the marketplace, and prices here would be similar (a bit higher in case Chuie buys it) and I *still* didn't put prices in. But my games will generally be available for cash.

This is [b]NOT[/b] for the Race For The Galaxy base game pictured.
Rather, it's for a deck of 69 cards that forms an excellent stand-alone expansion for the base set of Race For The Galaxy. It was designed by the BGG user Voxen [user=Voxen][/user]You can see the expansion in this Geeklist: [geeklist=66275][/geeklist] It introduces nine new Start Worlds, Galactic Agendas (an alternative to Prestige and Goals), Peaceful Worlds, "Intel" Powers and more.
I printed out the cards as a deck from Artscow, with the backs being the same as regular Race For The Galaxy cards. Artscow cards are slightly larger than RFTG cards, so you should shuffle carefully/thoroughly. Note that you will have to print out your own Agenda cards (there are five of them), as this deck only contains the cards that are shuffled into the deck that the players draw from.
This is a great way to satisfy your desire for new Race For The Galaxy cards while we wait for the release of the Alien Artifacts expansion!
Excellent/New Condition.

Good Condition.
This is a *serious* paste-up job of the German version of the game (Geschichten aus 1001 Nacht). But it is much more than a simple paste-up. [b]The Book Of Tales that comes with the game is greatly expanded from the original edition.[/b] The designer, Eric Goldberg, composed many more encounters and narrative paragraphs for a new edition, but it was never produced. However, he made the document available to a big fan of the game and that's where this copy came from. The original (German) rules are not included - though I have a print-out of the English rules from the West End Games version - so I cannot verify that all the components are here. However, I honestly believe they are and I have played this version with no problem. Again, the extensive paste-up job (board and cards) and the expanded English Book Of Tales makes this no problem to play for English speakers.
Trade or sell. I'm mostly interested in selling, but have run out of time to determine a price. If you're interested in buying, submit a fair amount for the game plus shipping on your want list and it might be yours if the Math Trade Fates allow!
If you want to make sure you get this, it would serve you well to contact me before the deadline for want lists passes...

For the Breese fan within you!
Fine Condition, except that it is missing a hexagonal brown counter. Instead, the game came with two(!) extra round brown counters. You can use one of the round counters to represent the missing hexagonal piece and the game is perfectly playable. And/or, you could probably contact R&D Games/Richard Breese and have him replace the missing piece; I just never bothered to pursue that. In this game, each player controls a fox, who wants to eat lots of birds, but each player also has certain birds he or she is trying to prevent being eaten.

Fun party game that gets you to think in a new way. Players read clues to their teammates, who then try to guess the answer, which will always be two rhyming words with the same number of syllables. "An obese feline" = "fat cat"; "a large Australian jumping marsupial that is late" = "overdue kangaroo".

Good for kids who want to be "cool" at the next dance party and/or anyone who's interested in an aerobic workout.
